awd_titl_txt: The Role Of Environmental Variation In The Appearance Of Agricultural Domesticates
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Robert Rosenswig, of the University at Albany-SUNY, along with colleagues from Penn State, Arizona State and the University of Central Washington, will undertake research on the origins of food production in Mesoamerica in relation to the changing climate and evolving tropical forest ecology. Food production is one of the most significant developments in the history of the human species. It has long been acknowledged as setting the stage for virtually all subsequent cultural developments by increasing the carrying capacity of land, the degree of sedentism that is possible as well as greater population density. As a result, the production of food was a required prerequisite for the establishment of urban life. Food production is also necessary to underwrite the division of labor within society that allowed farmers to support ever-increasing numbers of non-producers such as political rulers, engineers and scientists. Changes in climate are often posited as resulting in cultural collapse, but is evaluated in this research for its role in the intensification of food production. This project is significant in advancing basic understanding of interactions between the origins of human food production and tropical forest ecology in response to climate change in Mesoamerica, one of the small number of locations in the world where agriculture independently developed.

Dr. Rosenswig and his team will examine how drying environmental conditions impact human subsistence practices and how intensified food production, in turn, impact local vegetation patterns. The reconstruction of human occupation and forest floral species diversity in the tropical lowlands of northern Belize, Central America will be reconstructed from 4000-1000 BC to document how food production and settlement patterns were impacted by the changing climate and, in turn, how local vegetation was reconstituted. This will be accomplished by combining: 1. archaeological excavation that documents human habitation; 2. lake sediment coring to reconstruct changing patterns of plant pollen from economically useful species and 3. charcoal that result from human burning of local vegetation to increase soil productivity. Research will focus on the so-called "4.2k BP Event" that caused three centuries of climate disturbance world-wide between 2200 and 1900 BC. Evidence of human settlement patterns and diet from before, during and after this period will be used to evaluate paleoecological evidence of changing species availability and the extent of anthropogenic disturbance through the use of fire.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research is transformative in advancing basic understanding of interactions between human food production and tropical forest ecology in response to climate change. These are concerns as relevant to ancient Mesoamerican peoples as to 21st-century human populations, especially those dependent on subsistence farming in precarious tropical environments. Research focused on the so-called "4.2k BP Event" that caused three centuries of climate drying at mid-latitudes world-wide between 4200 and 3900 BP is associated with the collapse of ancient civilizations in Egypt, India and the Middle East. Climate change is often posited as resulting in cultural collapse, but here we explore its role in the intensification of food production which resulted in the remaking of tropical forest vegetation to create a domesticated niche more conducive to species useful for human subsistence. Climate changes during the fifth millennium BP provides a climatic “shock” that parallels current climatic changes and falls within the “Growing Convergent Research” priority of the NSF’s 10 Big Ideas, by protecting human health through better understanding of the nexus between food, climate and environmental change. Implications of our research is that responses to climate change are not uniform and depend on how human societies the environments in which they live.

 This project investigates the interaction between food production and tropical forest ecology in response to climate change in Mesoamerica, one of the small number of locations in the world where agriculture developed independently. Dr. Rosenswig and his team document how drying environmental conditions at the end of the 4th millennium BP (before present) impacted human food production in the tropical lowlands of northern Belize, Central America. Research is focused on the Archaic period from 6000-3000 years BP when mobile foragers occupied the region, and before the later Maya civilization for which Mesoamerica is famous. Research goals were accomplished by combining: 1- archaeological excavation that documents human habitation; 2- lake sediment coring to reconstruct changing vegetation patterns from plant pollen and 3- charcoal that result from human burning of local vegetation to increase soil productivity.

 The project documented 160 new archaeological sites through survey employing a distinctive orange soil to locate these ancient occupations. The project area covers 15 sq km and is the first systematic survey of Archaic-period occupation ever undertaken in Mesoamerica. Excavations were carried out at seventeen of these sites, with stone tools and carbon (used for dating) recovered from each locale. Radiocarbon dating documents that these sites were occupied during the 4th and 5th millennia BP and ongoing analysis of stone tools reveal how these foragers hunted and cultivated plants across the survey zone. Prepared cobble surfaces were documented at two sites and formed living surfaces. These cobble surfaces were contained in the orange soil horizon and have carbon remains embedded in them as well as debitage from stone tool manufacture. These prepared living surfaces are some of the first open-air domestic sites documented from lowland Mesoamerica dated to the Archaic period.

 A campaign of paleoenvironmental reconstruction was concurrently undertaken with the analysis of six sediment cores collected from lakes in the project area. Preliminary dating of the cores documents a paleoenvironmental record extending back 8,000 years with dramatic increases of charcoal entering the lake sediments during the 3rd millennium BP when ceramic-using villagers were first documented. Each of these cores contain a distinctive pink colored layer in the inundated lake bottom sediments that dates to the same time as the orange horizon on shore where Archaic period sites were documented. The pink horizon dated to the fourth millennium BP and indicates that food production was enhanced in response to climatic events.

 The project consisted of four field seasons during which time 21 graduate and undergraduate students (including 11 women, 5 Latino Americans s and 1 African American) received archaeological and paleoenvironmental research training. Project results were shared with local constituencies in Belize through three public lectures as well as site visits by local landowners. Three dimensional printings of Archaic-period stone tools documented by the project were donated to the Belize Institute of Archaeology and used for elementary school public outreach and education events.
